comments.content:
@jk0: 

Looking at the test failures at http://logs.openstack.org/32549/3/check/gate-nova-python27/25158/console.html,
the command that the test tried to execute using nova's rootwrap was:

COMMAND=/home/jenkins/workspace/gate-nova-python27/.tox/py27/bin/nova-rootwrap /etc/nova/rootwrap.conf rm /tmp/tmp.WVIZziaxuv/tmp_2n7x0/tmpbuRC0e/instance-fake.log 

I am not sure if the CI infrastructure will allow this as it is attempting to 
perform 'rm' operation as a root user which is unsafe. But the test above fails.

Also, adding 'root' user to libvirtd group on compute node  does not really either 

While looking at the patch:
log_file_path = '%s/%s.log' % (CONF.libvirt_log_path, instance_name)

Assuming this libvirt_log_path = /var/log/libvirt ,  and as  /var/log is owned 
by 'root' user, then in the utils.execute, run_as_root=True is acceptable.

If the libvirt_log_path is configured to another path that is not owned by root,  say /opt/data/logs/xyz, 
then we don't need 'run_as_root=True' to execute the command.

By adding '/bin/rm' to the compute filter and running it as root in the code is unsafe if some intrusive tests are added.
Thoughts on how this issue be addressed in CI, or code?

comments.content:
Libvirt already installs a logrotate file to handle cleanup of the logs on a regular basis

  /etc/logrotate.d/libvirtd.qemu


If the frequency of cleanup here is not sufficient for a particular deployment, then admin can just edit the settings of that config file.  We should not duplicate logrotate functionality in Nova.
